questions.question_text:
An administrator configured a Security policy rule where the matching condition includes a single application and the action is set to deny.

What deny action will the firewall perform?

choices.A: Discard the session’s packets and send a TCP reset packet to let the client know the session has been terminated
choices.C: Perform the default deny action as defined in the App-ID database for the application
choices.D: Send a TCP reset packet to the client- and server-side devices

discussion.content:
C. Perform the default deny action as defined in the App-ID database for the application

When a Security policy rule is set to deny and it matches a single application, the firewall will perform the default deny action as defined in the App-ID database for the application1. If no Deny Action is listed in the App-ID description, the packets will be silently discarded

Selected Answer: C
C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
Deny action on security policy rule initiate the default deny action for matched app on security profile.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-admin/policy/security-policy/security-policy-actions

choices.D:
Source Zone: Trusted -

Destination Zone: DMZ -

Services: SSH -

Applications: Any -
Action: Deny
choices.C:
Source Zone: Trusted -

Destination Zone: DMZ -

Services: Application-Default -

Applications: SSH -
Action: Deny
choices.A:
Source Zone: Trusted -

Destination Zone: DMZ -

Services: SSH -

Applications: Any -
Action: Allow
choices.B:
Source Zone: Trusted -

Destination Zone: DMZ -

Services: Application-Default -

Applications: SSH -
Action: Allow

discussion.content: B - This configuration allows the firewall to identify the SFTP traffic (which uses the SSH protocol) and permit it from the Trusted zone to the DMZ zone1. The ‘Application-Default’ service setting ensures that only the standard ports for the specified application (SSH in this case) are allowed

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
"Select SSH as the application and set the service to application-default."
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClHtCAK

questions.question_text: If users from the Trusted zone need to allow traffic to an SFTP server in the DMZ zone, how should a Security policy with App-ID be configured?

choices.C: It allows the traffic because the profile was not set the explicitly deny the traffic.
choices.B: It drops the traffic because the profile was not set to explicitly allow the traffic.
choices.D: It uses the default action assigned to the virus signature.
choices.A: It allows the traffic but generates an entry in the Threat logs.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Security profiles have their own actions

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
"Default—For each threat signature and Antivirus signature that is defined by Palo Alto Networks, a default action is specified internally. Typically, the default action is an alert or a reset-both. "
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/policy/security-profiles

questions.question_text:
An administrator configured a Security policy rule with an Antivirus Security profile. The administrator did not change the action for the profile.

If a virus gets detected, how will the firewall handle the traffic?

An administrator needs to allow users to use only certain email applications.

How should the administrator configure the firewall to restrict users to specific email applications?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
key word : only certain application
so application group is the answer

ANSWER C

Keyword here is "certain applications. By selection B, you will allow all application within that subcategory to be allowed. 
With Answer C, you choose only the apps you need/want.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct, B would block all e-mail applications. The questions states we want to block only some e-mail applications, which we can manually specify with an application group.

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer

Selected Answer: B
There is a mistake 
Collaboration category and email subcategory are exist, so application filter is correct answer

choices.D: Create an application group and add the email category to it.
choices.B: Create an application filter and filter it on the collaboration category, email subcategory.
choices.C: Create an application group and add the email applications to it.
choices.A: Create an application filter and filter it on the collaboration category.

questions.question_text: DNS exceptions can be set under which Security profile?

discussion.content:
guide me DNS also can exception done on URL filtering ..
Steps to Set DNS Exceptions:
Navigate to Security Profiles: Go to the Policies tab, then select Security Profiles.
Select URL Filtering: Choose the URL Filtering profile you wish to modify or create a new one.
Add Exceptions: In the URL Filtering profile, look for an option to add exceptions. Here you can specify the domains you want to exempt from filtering.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct
"Object -> Anti-spyware profile -> DNS Exceptions "
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000PPdBCAW
